name: bin
content:
bin

noun
 
 
/bɪn/
 
/bɪn/
jump to other results
  1.  
     (especially British English) a container that you put waste in
    • a rubbish bin
    • Grey bins will be emptied weekly.
    • Many councils now have fortnightly bin collections.
    see also dustbin, green bin, litter bin, waste bin, wheelie bin
    Extra Examples
    • Put the bottles in the recycling bin.
    • She threw the letter in the waste-paper bin.
    Topics Houses and homesa2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • litter
    • rubbish
    • waste
    • …
    verb + bin
    • put something in
    • chuck something in/​into
    • throw something in/​into
    • …
    bin + noun
    • bag
    • liner
    • man
    • …
    preposition
    • in a/​the bin
    See full entry
  2. a large container, usually with a lid (= cover), for storing things in
    • a bread bin
    • All their toys are kept in plastic storage bins under the bed.
    see also compost bin
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • litter
    • rubbish
    • waste
    • …
    verb + bin
    • put something in
    • chuck something in/​into
    • throw something in/​into
    • …
    bin + noun
    • bag
    • liner
    • man
    • …
    preposition
    • in a/​the bin
    See full entry
    3. Word OriginOld English bin(n), binne, of Celtic origin; related to Welsh ben ‘cart’. The original meaning was ‘container’ in a general sense; also specifically ‘a container for animal food in a stable’ and ‘container for grain, bread, or other foodstuffs’. The sense ‘container for rubbish’ dates from the mid 19th cent.
See bin in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: bin

name: bin
content:
bin

verb
 
/bɪn/
 
/bɪn/
(British English, informal)
Verb Forms
present simple I / you / we / they bin
 
/bɪn/
 
/bɪn/
he / she / it bins
 
/bɪnz/
 
/bɪnz/
past simple binned
 
/bɪnd/
 
/bɪnd/
past participle binned
 
/bɪnd/
 
/bɪnd/
-ing form binning
 
/ˈbɪnɪŋ/
 
/ˈbɪnɪŋ/
jump to other results
  1. bin something to throw something away
    • Do you need to keep these letters or shall we bin them?
    • Sorry—I’ve already binned it.
    Word OriginOld English bin(n), binne, of Celtic origin; related to Welsh ben ‘cart’. The original meaning was ‘container’ in a general sense; also specifically ‘a container for animal food in a stable’ and ‘container for grain, bread, or other foodstuffs’. The sense ‘container for rubbish’ dates from the mid 19th cent.

name: sin bin
content:
sin bin

noun
 
/ˈsɪn bɪn/
 
/ˈsɪn bɪn/
(informal)
jump to other results
  1. (in some sports, for example ice hockey) a place away from the playing area where the referee sends a player who has broken the rules for a period of time before they are allowed to come back into the game
See sin bin in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary

name: green bin
content:
green bin

noun
 
/ˈɡriːn bɪn/
 
/ˈɡriːn bɪn/
(especially Canadian English)
jump to other results
  1. a green plastic container in which you can put waste that will break down into the soil, such as fruit, vegetables, etc., for refuse collectors to take away
    • Because there are no green bins, the compost has to be thrown out with the garbage.
See green bin in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: green bin
